name: MGM Resorts and Caesars Entertainment Attacks
summary: Scattered Spider (UNC3944) conducted highly sophisticated social engineering attacks against MGM Resorts and Caesars Entertainment, partnering with ALPHV/BlackCat for ransomware deployment. The attacks demonstrated the effectiveness of phone-based social engineering (vishing) against enterprise IT help desks.

attack_phases.name: Social Engineering Reconnaissance
attack_phases.description: Attackers researched employees via LinkedIn and social media to gather personal information for impersonation.

attack_phases.name: Vishing Attack on Help Desk
attack_phases.description: Attackers called IT help desk impersonating employees, using personal details to bypass verification. Convinced help desk to reset MFA and provide access.

social_engineering_details.method: Phone call to IT help desk
social_engineering_details.pretext: Employee locked out, needs password/MFA reset
social_engineering_details.success_factor: Native English speakers with employee knowledge

attack_phases.name: Initial Access and Persistence
attack_phases.description: Using reset credentials, attackers accessed Okta admin portal and created additional accounts for persistence.

attack_phases.name: Identity Provider Compromise
attack_phases.description: Attackers compromised identity infrastructure, gaining access to federated applications and cloud resources.

attack_phases.name: Lateral Movement and Data Collection
attack_phases.description: Moved through cloud and on-premises infrastructure, accessing email, documents, and sensitive systems.

attack_phases.name: Ransomware Deployment (MGM)
attack_phases.description: ALPHV/BlackCat ransomware deployed across MGM infrastructure, encrypting over 100 ESXi hypervisors.

operational_disruption.properties_affected: All MGM properties (Bellagio, MGM Grand, Mandalay Bay, etc.)

caesars_impact.data_stolen: Driver's license and SSN for loyalty program members

help_desk: MFA device changes for privileged accounts

lessons_learned: Help desk procedures must include strong verification
MFA alone is insufficient against social engineering
Young attackers can be highly sophisticated
